div.p: The Firſt Part OF Dr. Fauſtus, Abreviated and brought into VERSE. SHEWING The Wickedneſs of his, Life, and the Tyranny of the Devil; who after he had inſnared him by Deluſions and large promiſes of 24 Years proſperiry threatned to pull and tear him in pieces when he ſeemed to Repent. With many other things worthy to be minded.

figure.figDesc: depiction of a robed male figure or Doctor Faustus holding a book or staff and standing within a circle of alchemical and zodiacal symbols; outside the circle is a devil or demon; there is an open window in the wall and on the wall are an empty bird-cage, a cross or crucifix, and many books; c.f. the title page of the 1616 John Wright edition of Marlowe's 'The tragicall history of the life and death of Doctor Faustus'

div.p: Printed by I. M. for I. Deacon, and C: Denniſſon, and are to be ſold at their Shops, at the Angel in Guilt-ſpur-Street and at the Stationers-Arms within Aldgate

div.head: THE FIRST PART OF Doctor Fauſtus. SHEWING The VVickedneſs of his Life.
CHAP. I. The place of his Birth and Education.
div.l: STrange news I from the German Empire bring
A true account of a moſt horrid thing;
Done by one Doctor Fauſtus call'd by name,
Who by deluſion Satan overcame.
At Wittenberg this Fauſtus he did dwell,
A place in Germany is known full well;
His Uncle brought him up moſt carefully;
Putting him to the Univerſity;
Twas his good old Uncles plain deſign,
That he ſhould ſtudy what is call'd divine:
But he inclined was to Sin by Nature,
And minded not the will of his Creator:
Giving himſelf to wicked exerciſe,
Forſaking that which only makes men wiſe;
And Negromancy he did ſtudy ſo,
That thereby he wrought his ſouls overthrow;
In ſinful manner then by day and night,
He ſpent his precious time, and took delight
In nothing elſe but what we count moſt Evil,
Offending God, to gratifie the Devil.

div.head: CHAP. II. how Doctor Fauſtus began his deviliſh Act.
div.l: POor Fauſtus thus deluded and undone,
His joys did vaniſh, and his woe begun;
For Satan evermore doth take great care,
To bring poor mortal men into a ſnare.
Fauſtus moſt Helliſh arts then underſtood,
And privately he haſted to a Wood,
Not diſtant far from whence he then did dwell,
And there invok'd a Damned Fiend of Hell;
And Mephoſtophiles he call'd his Name,
Who ſoon appeared in a dreadful flame:
Half frighted was he at this fearful ſight,
Which was about the hour of ten at night;
For at his coming he ſo loud did roar;
The frightned artiſt thought to call no more.
This Helliſh Fiend, which when the Devil knew,
He thought by policy him to ſubdue;
When he perceiv'd that he was ſo affrighted,
He ſtudies how to make him be delighted:
And ſtraightway he ſuch pleaſant muſick hears,
As ne'r before did fill his joyful Ears.
Theſe warbling Charms exceedingly did pleaſe,
No ſhape of man as yet the Doctor ſees:
But hopes, that in a very ſhort time he,
So much deſired without all doubt ſhould ſee;
So Mephoſtophiles he calls again,
Conjuring him by curſed Pluto's Name:
When on a ſudden o're the Doctors head,
A mighty Dragon plainly hovered:
And in the Wood was ſuch a diſmal cry,
As if Hell would have open'd inſtantly:
And after that a flaſhing fiery flame,
Forth with a fiend immediately there came,
About the Circle that the Doctor made,
This beaſt did run, yet he was not affraid:
So for a time he ſeem'd to dance the Hay,
At laſt appear'd like to a Fryar in Gray:
What's thy requeſt? then did this Fryar ſay,
Tell me your mind and make you no delay.
To which the Doctor ſtraight way did reply,
Tomorrow wait on me, and don't deny,
At twelve a Clock come to me here be ſure,
but theſe commands the fryar could not endure
Till Fauſtus did by Belzehub Conjure.
The Spirit then did ſoon thereto agree,
The Doctor then homeward returned he.

div.head: CHAP. III. The Doctors Conference with the Devil at his own Houſe.
div.l: THe hour appointed quickly did draw near,
And Mephoſtophiles did there appear:
So Doctor Fauſtus did him thus Conjure,
All my commands you muſt obey be ſure;
Anſwer me true to all that I ſhall ask,
Fulfil my mind, for this muſt be your task:
Firſt, from this time ſo long as I have breath
Obey my will until the hour of death.
And ſecondly, what thing ſo e're I crave,
See that the ſame I inſtantly may have;
And thirdly, all that I ſhall ask of you,
What you reply, let e'ry word be true.
To which the Spirit quickly anſwer made,
He could not grant to all that he had ſaid;
But firſt he muſt acquaint his Prince with all,
For we our Rulers ſtill do princes call;
And thou thy ſelf doſt very much deceive,
To think I can do this without his leave;
And let me tell you Fauſtus, we as well,
A Kingdom have in our dark Pit of Hell,
As you on Earth, we Rulers have 'tis known,
And Servants too, for I my ſelf am one:
But Lucifer he is the Chief of all,
Inſulting pride procur'd his deadly fall;
Yet there's a Legion of Devils there
At his command, and of him ſtand in fear.
The Doctor then enrag'd, thus anſwered he,
I'le have my will, and will not Damned be.
The Spirit ſaid, thou ſhalt want thy deſire,
And yet ſhalt burn in neve-rceaſing fire;
Thy Infidelity thy ruine wrought,
And after death thou wilt to Hell be brought,
The Spirit then did vaniſh quite away,
And Fauſtus he did in his Cloſet ſtay;
Reſolving that his will he would have done,
Though he did yield to what they ſtood upon.

div.head: CHAP. IV. The Spirits ſecond Apparition to Fauſtus.
div.l: THus where there the Spirit Fauſtus ſtaid,
Till night approach'd, and little was afraid
At laſt the ſwiſt-wing'd Spirit to him came,
Ask what thou wilt, quoth he, i'le do the ſame
My Prince commands me for to tell thee this,
He'l be at thy command, wilt thou be his?
The Spirit askt the Doctor his requeſt,
Come tell me truly, Fauſtus do not jeſt.
Then Fauſtus fainting, made him this reply,
Thou Damned art become, and ſo would I,
If thou wilt to theſe articles agree,
Firſt, that I may a Devil be like thee:
And ſecondly, thou night and day ſhalt ſtand,
To wait on me, and do what I command.
Thirdly, if I do covet any thing,
Let it be what it will, thou muſt it bring.
Fourthly, thou ſhalt at all times preſent be,
Within my Houſe, and none but I ſee thee.
Laſtly, when I would have thee to come here,
In what ſhape I do pleaſe thou ſhalt appear,
The Spirit told him, wilt thou yield to me,
The things thou doſt deſire ſhall granted be:
Firſt, thou to Lucifer thy Soul ſhalt give,
& ſerve him whilſt on Earth thou here doſt live.
And ſecondly, this muſt be underſtood,
He'l have a Writing written with thy blood.
Thirdly, thou ſhalt all Chriſtian people hate,
Who ſerve the God who firſt did thee create,
And of theſe terms, the fourth muſt be the chief,
Thou muſt deny the Chriſtian Belief.
Fifthly, that thou ſhalt any man deny,
Who from theſe Principles would have thee flye,
Then Satan promiſed to Fauſtus, he
Should many years live in Proſperity:
And when thou dyeſt, the Spirit then did ſay,
The Fiends of Hell ſhall fetch thee quite away?
But wicked Fauſtus did to this agree,
So Damn'd his Soul to all Eternity.

div.head: CHAP. V. The third Parly between Fauſtus and Mephoſtophiles.
div.l: WHen Fauſtus had his precious Soul betray'd,
and to the Devil had this promiſe made,
He call'd his Spirit on him to attend,
Who from th' infernal Lake did ſoon aſcend;
Commanding him, like a Franciſcan Fryar,
Still to appear, for it was his deſire:
And like St. Anthany come with a Bell,
That of his coming he might know full well.
Fauſtus demanded then the Spirits name,
Who very willingly told him the ſame:
My name is Mephoſtophiles; ſaid he,
And am a Prince that now doth wait on thee.
Thus Fauſtus was content with his Souls loſs,
But ſmeet meats often have the ſoureſt ſauce.
This Obligation Fauſtus was to make,
Which he performed for his promiſe-ſake;
And with a Pen-knife he did make a wound,
And writ the words that did his Soul confound

div.head: CHAP: VI. Fauſtus warms his Blood in a Sawter and writ •• as followeth.
div.l: I Doctor Fauſtus do confeſs your due
Is for to have both Soul and Body too;
I with my Pen the ſame do now declare;
Writ with my hand, ſeal'd with my blood they,
Provided you your promiſe do make good,
Which by the Lines above are underſtood:
That after twenty-four years do expire,
If I before ſatisfie my deſire.
And what I do command you do obey,
You then ſhall carry Fauſtus hence away:
In the mean time I do expect to have
The power to raiſe dead bodies from the grave
And have at will whatever I deſire,
By your aſſiſtance, e're theſe years expire:
And if what I deſire you grant to me,
Then Lucifer, Fauſtus ſhall come to thee.

div.head: CHAP. VII. How the Spirit came for his Writing, in what ſhape, and what he ſhewed him; cauſing him to keep a Coppy of his own Writing.
div.l: AS Doctor Fauſtus was pauſing alone,
Except 1 boy, then with him there was none;
The Spirit ſuddenly unto him came,
Appearing in a dreadful fiery Flame;
The Boy affrighted was and much diſmay'd,
His Maſter bid him not to be afraid,
No harm ſhould come to him, the Spirit then
Began to ſhew ſome pretty tricks agen;
Which pleaſed Fauſtus moſt exceeding well,
Such tricks before he ne'r ſee come from Hell:
A mighty Army preſently appear'd,
Trampling of Horſes too by them was heard;
And after this a pack of greedy Hounds,
Did chaſe a Hart ſeemingly through the grounds
This ceaſing, then appeared to their ſight,
A Lyon and a Dragon both in fight,
The Dragon over came the Lyon then,
Away the Dragon vaniſht to his Den.
A Peacock and a Pea-Hen then came in,
To beat the Hen, the Peacock did begin:
He bruſſling of his tayl, beat her ſo ſore,
They vaniſht then, and ſo was ſeen no more.
A furious Bull came in at Fauſtus run,
But vaniſht e're any harm was done:
A ſudden miſt upon them then did fall,
And Fauſtus he could ſee no light at all,
But when the light appear'd he did behold
Two Sacks; one full of Silver, one of Gold.
Laſtly, ſuch pleaſant muſick he did hear,
that pleas'd him, yet nothing did appear:
At laſt did Mephoſtophiles come in,
And thus to treat him Fauſtus did begin:
So well thou now haſt pleas'd me in my mind,
That if ſuch paſtime I can always find,
My mind i • le never change, but thou ſhalt ſee,
Both Soul and Body I will give to thee.
But Mephoſtophiles did ſoon reply,
With greater wonders I will pleaſe thine Eye
Command me what thou wilt and thou ſhalt ſee
I in a moment will provide it thee;
But firſt I want the Writing thou haſt made,
Give me but that, I'le do what I have ſaid,
Then ſtretching forth his hand, here take, ſaid he
The Writing that I did provide for thee.
And Mephoſtophiles thus to him ſpake,
Wiſhing that he ſhould a coppy take;
Which being done, together they did ſtay,
He waited on the Doctor night and day.

div.head: CHAP. VIII. Fauſtus's Damnable Proceeding, and the Devils diligence.
div.l: WHen Fauſtus finiſht had his curſt deſign,
He then grew bold, & did no whit repine,
His Helliſh Servant ſtill was diligent,
To fill his Maſters mind with all content:
For what ſoe're he did deſire to eat,
Though hollow Fowls, or any other meat;
Or did he wiſh to taſt all ſorts of Wine,
That were on this ſide or beyond the Line:
Or were it all the World, be't what it will.
This Devil would his luſtful mind fullfil,
And from great Dukes would ſteal them all away
What he deſire'd was quickly made his prey,
Sy by this means his God he ſoon forgot,
And that he mortal was ſuppoſed not.

div.head: CHAP. IX. How Fauſtus would have Married, and how the Devil beat him for it.
div.l: FAuſtus not dreaming he had ſo miſcarried,
Forgot his promiſe, & would needs be married
His Spirit thereunto would not agree,
But bid him be content, it could not be,
Thou haſt indented unto the contrary,
And do you now intend for to forſwear ye?
No, no, be ſure you mind what you have ſworn
Or elſe in pieces you will ſoon be torn:
Marriage appointed is by God, then why
Should you mind that who muſt for ever fry?
The Doctor hearing this, fell in diſpair,
Fearing the Devil would in pieces tear
His curſed Body, and did then deny,
And after this I Marriage will defie.
Thou haſt done well, quoth he, but now behold;
His flaming fancy was not yet grown cold:
But ſoon his ſpirit call'd to him again,
And thus to him began for to complain,
I can't ſubdue my fancy for my Life,
I muſt and will by all means have a Wife:
Without one I can never be content,
Then unto this I prithee give conſent.
A mighty VVhirl-wind then there did ariſe,
Which did the Doctor much with fear ſurprize.
And afterwards the Houſe ſo ſtrangely ſmoak'd,
That the poor Doctor he was almoſt choakd,
Then up the ſtairs he ran with might and main,
But quickly he was tumbled down again:
And flames of fire in circles round him run,
The Doctor then cry'd out he was undone;
Come now and help me this one time, quoth he,
To my Subſcription I will faithful be.
Another Devil then to him appear'd
So ugly, that poor Fauſtus was afear'd
To look on him, and thus the Fiend did ſay,
Fauſtus how doſt thou like thy wedding day?
How then to anſwer was to him unknown,
But pardon then he begg'd of him alone.

div.head: CHAP. X. Queſtions asked by Fauſtus of his Spirit Mephoſtophilis.
div.l: AFter this time Fauſtus did ſtrangely live,
And wholly did himſelf to pleaſure give,
So on a time he did his Spirit call,
And askt him how his Maſter came to fall
From Heavens joys into the pains of Hell
To this the Spirit preſently reply'd,
The great and chiefeſt cauſe of this was pride,
For God made him an Angel for to be,
To live with him in bleſt Eternity:
But he aſpiring, too great was his pride,
And now muſt be for ever terrify'd.

div.head: CHAP. XI. More Queſtions asked by Fauſtus of his Spirit Mephoſtophiles, concerning Hell.
div.l: The following night fauſtus he ſtrangly dream'd
And in his dream affrighted much he ſeem'd
He thought he plainly ſaw a part of Hell,
But what it was, he could by no means tell;
And waking, he did for his ſpirit call,
That he by him might know the truth of all;
And being come, he took him unto task,
Then did he of him ſeveral Queſtions ask:
What's Hell qd. he? & of what ſubſtance made?
Where does it ſtand? to whom the ſpirit ſaid,
Thou ſoon ſhalt know there was no Hell at all,
Before great Lucſfer's unhappy fall;
And after that was preſently ordain'd,
A place for wicked Devils to be chain'd;
What ſubſtance it is of, no Devils know,
But 'tis a ſtrange confuſed place below;
Of a foundation none of us can tell,
So ſtrange a place is our accurſed Hell;
No end not bottom there is I believe,
Experience an account in time will give.

div.head: CHAP. XII. More Queſtions asked by Fauſtus, (Viz.) What Kingdoms was in Hell, and what the Rulers Names was?
div.l: Fauſtus again deſires ſtrange things to know,
And Mephoſtophiles calls from below,
Strange things, quoth he, thou haſt aready told,
Now one thing more I pray thee to unfold.

l.hi: What Kingdoms are there where the Devils dwell
Or what call you their Names that rule in Hell?

div.l: My Fauſtus then, quoth he thou ſoon ſhalt know,
There is ten Kingdoms that we have below:
There's Lucus Morbis, Stagnuia, Ignis too,
And Terra Tenchroſa, this is true:
The fourth is Tartarus, and there one is,
By dwellers there, call'd Terra Oblivonis;
The ſixth Gehenna, the next Erebus,
And theſe are names that common are with us:
There's Barathrum, and Setix, and Athiron,
I think I ſhall have nam'd them all anon.
Lucifer governs o're the Orient,
And Aſceroth doth Rule the Orident.
And Belzehub rules in Septertrio;
And Bellal in Meredid, I do know,
Phlegeton is i'th middle of them all,
The greateſt Sinners thereinto do fall.

div.head: CHAP. XIII. Fauſtus begins to repent his wicked deed.
div.l: Fauſtus was ne'r with Queſtions ſatisfi'd,
But ſtill ask't more concerning Pluto's pride;
What was he, when quoth he, he liv'd above,
Bleſt with the Smiles of great Iehovah's love?
To which the Spirit preſently ſtood mute,
And beg'd he'd give him 3 days time to do't?
Three days expir'd, he then this anſwer gave,
Lucifer now, a damn'd accurſed Slave,
Was then above, an Angel clear and bright,
In whom the great Creator took delight:
But he did covet Gods Almighty Throne,
And is therefore made an accurſed one.
At firſt he did ſurpaſs the Glorious Sun,
Now by his Pride, for ever he's undone:
In Heaven he had a Kingly Office great,
Now baniſht from the Almighty's bleſſed Seat.
The Doctor minding what the Spirit ſaid,
Grew penſive, and in heart almoſt afraid;
Into his Chamber ſtraightway then he went,
Oppreſt with care, and fill'd with diſcontent:
Ah, woe is me, quoth he, what have I done?
I've loſt that Kingdom which I might have Won
I once Gods Image wore, but now I ſee,
I from his preſence baniſhed muſt be:
With Lucifer I muſt in torments dwell,
My Pride, like his, hath caſt me into Hell.

div.head: CHAP. XIV. Fauſtus asketh the Spirit the Devils Power and Enmity to Mankind in this manner.
div.l: FAuſtus unſatisfied, ask Queſtions ſtill,
Thinking to compaſs his ambitious will:
Quoth he, now tell me truly, whats the cauſe,
That Satan ſtill doth violate Gods Laws?
For I do well obeſrve he is inclin'd,
To ſeek the utter ruine of mankind.
To which the Spirit ſtraightway did reply,
When Lucifer was curſt by God on high,
And caſt into this utter darkneſs then,
An Enemy he grew to God and Men:
He cauſes all the wickedneſs that is,
And he's the cauſe ſo many does amiſs;
Some fall into diſpair, and cruelly
Lay hands upon themſelves and murdering dye:
He cauſed Adam firſt for to tranſgreſs,
And then began all Mens unhappineſs:
He was the cauſe poor Abel he was ſlain,
By that his unkind Brother Cain;
By him all fleſh into Rebellion run,
And he's the cauſe if all the World's undone.

div.head: CHAP. XV. Fauſtus deſires to know more of Hell, and whether the Devils might ever come into Favour with God.
div.l: FAuſtus diſpairing of all mercy then,
Doth call his ſpirit to diſcourſe agen;
Tell me, quoth he, how do the Damned dwell?
What pains do they endure that are in Hell?
Will the Almighty e're be reconcil'd,
To him who fain would have his God beguil'd
Forbear, quoth he, do not ſuch queſtions raiſe,
They' breed but trouble to thee all thy days.
Quoth Fauſtus, I muſt know or i'le not live,
Then did the Spirit him this anſwer give:
Forth from the Lake of Hell, 'twas never known
That ever any came, except 'twere one;
With him thou nothing haſt to do, 'tis plain,
Thoſe that are Damn'd muſt ſtill in Hell remain.
There is ſuch pains that tongue cannot expreſs,
The wrath of God, and endleſs bitterneſs:
Sometimes they burn in flames, none can endure,
And ſometimes froſts their torments do procure,
To go about to tell you, all's in vain,
For tongue cannot expreſs their endleſs pain
That damned Souls do feel, in Hell that lye,
Doth burn and freeze, and yet they cannot dye:
And now O Fauſtus! let me tell to thee,
All this and more will ſure thy portion be.
When thou doſt come to be with us in Hell,
Thou ſhalt be poyſon'd with a noyſom ſmell.
There thou ſhalt grow deaf, thy hand ſhall tremble
The Devils with their firebrands ſhall be nimble
To toſs thee too and fro, from one to th'other,
〈◊〉 ſtinking brimſtone ſhall them almoſt ſmother.
Thou ſhalt tormented be, but ſhall not flye,
Thou then ſhalt wiſh for death, but ſhalt not dye,
And to be ſhort, thy pains ſhall ſtill encreaſe,
Never to end, nor never to find eaſe,
And more & moe thy plagues ſhall thee torment
What-ſayſt thou now? can this breed thy content?
How lik'ſt thou this that I relate to thee,
This is the ſtate wherein the Damned be.

figure.figDesc: depiction of a robed male figure or Doctor Faustus holding a book or staff and standing within a circle of alchemical and zodiacal symbols; outside the circle is a devil or demon; there is an open window in the wall and on the wall are an empty bird-cage, a cross or crucifix, and many books; c.f. the title page of the 1616 John Wright edition of Marlowe's 'The tragicall history of the life and death of Doctor Faustus'
